citation.article-title: Characterization of a novel halophilic archaeon, Halobiforma haloterrestris gen. nov., sp. nov., and transfer of Natronobacterium nitratireducens to Halobiforma nitratireducens comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Halobiforma haloterrestris sp. nov.
Halobiforma haloterrestris (ha.lo.ter.res'tris. Gr. n. hals, halos salt; L. adj. terrestris belonging to the soil; N.L. adj. haloterrestris from salty soil)
Cells are pigmented and are rods that measure 0.5-1.5¬2-8 μm, pleomorphic and cocci that measure 1.25-2.0 μm in diameter.
Cells are Gram-negative and are motile.
Only rods lyse in distilled water or 1% (w/v) bacto-peptone.
The optimum temperature for growth is 42 °C.
The pH range for growth is pH 6-9.2, with an optimum at pH 7.5.
The NaCl range for growth is 2.2 M to saturation, with an optimum of 3.4 MNaCl.NaCl may be replaced to a large extent by KCl.
Acid is produced from xylose, arabinose, glucose, sucrose and maltose, but not from lactose, fructose, galactose or starch or urea.
Casein and gelatin are hydrolysed, but not starch.
Tweens 20, 40 and 80 are also hydrolysed, but not egg yolk (lecithin).
NH4 cannot serve as a nitrogen source, while organic nitrogen compounds such as proteose peptone, Casamino acids and tryptone can serve as nitrogen, carbon and energy sources.
The G­C content of the DNA is 66.9 mol%.
Isolated from a salt soil close to Aswan (Egypt).
